channel.title: linux on I Prefer Jim
channel.description: Recent content in linux on I Prefer Jim

item.title: Data at the root level is invalid. Line 1, position 1.
item.description: Recently, I encountered a really weird problem with an XML document. I was trying to load a document from a string:

item.title: Hard link in OS X
item.description: Under linux, I used mount --bind olddir newdir to link a source code directory from a git repository in my Dropbox folder to another public git repository.

item.title: System76 notebooks… are they worth the money?
item.description: On June 19 2012, I purchased a 15″ Pangolin Performance with the following configuration: Ubuntu 12.04 LTS 64 bit 15.

item.title: Reformat README.md (or other text files) to fixed width
item.description:
Fixed width README.md? Sure.

fold README.md -w 80 -s README.md — Jim Schubert (@jimschubert) June 15, 2014

item.title: Install Balsamiq, Ubuntu 14.04
item.description: Balsamiq for Desktop requires Adobe AIR, which is no longer supported. Here are the steps I took to get AIR and Balsamiq to install.

item.title: Disable scrollbar overlays in Ubuntu 13.10
item.description: Working with Tizen IDE, I noticed the overlay doesn’t actually display for the scrollbar in Ubuntu 13.10. This isn’t so bad for vertical scrolling because I use the touchpad to scroll.

item.title: Tizen SDK 2.2.1 on Ubuntu 13.10
item.description: I’ve registered for the Tizen Seattle Devlab & Hack which takes place on December 6-7 2013. To prepare, I downloaded and installed the Tizen SDK.

item.title: bash function: md.view
item.description: One of my favorite bash functions is md.view, which is available in my dotfiles repository. # test markdown files, probably a better way to test for programs.

item.title: ‘Upgrading’ couchdb on Ubuntu 12.04
item.description: If you’ve installed couchdb from the Ubuntu repositories, you’re likely running 1.0.1. If you decide to build and install couchdb from source, you may have some issues with the server starting after a reboot.

item.title: Ubuntu: Open With… Wireshark
item.description: Reading through Practical Packet Analysis, I ran local captures to follow along until Chapter 5. Instead of trying to simulate an improperly-dissected packet, I downloaded the captures which accompany the book.

item.title: dotfiles backup using GitHub
item.description: I was recently looking for a solution to backup my configuration files (bash, vim, etc) using GitHub. After some looking around, I’ve compiled a pretty nice project for myself.

item.title: Mercurial and Git in one repository
item.description: I have a personal project hosted at bitbucket using Mercurial as the version control system. Since I started that project, I’ve been using GitHub for everything.

item.title: Running additional Google Chrome profiles in Linux
item.description: Google Chrome supports running multiple profiles. In newer versions of Google Chrome, you’ll be able to enable profiles by navigating to chrome://flags and enabling Multiple Profiles.

item.title: Linux tip: Alias ‘cd’ in bash shell
item.description: A while ago, I stumbled across an excellent article at O’Reilly with tips for your bash shell. I wanted to expand on the “pushd/popd” section a little.
